item.title: Mothership‚Äôs box set gives newbie game masters something to hold on to | Polygon - Gaming
item.description: Image: Tuesday Knight Games Don‚Äôt give up the ship All too often, tabletop role-playing games get lost in their own fine print. As the author of a core rulebook, you want to keep things short and sw...
item.content:encoded: Image: Tuesday Knight Games Don‚Äôt give up the ship All too often, tabletop role-playing games get lost in their own fine print. As the author of a core rulebook, you want to keep things short and sweet, but it can be easy to confuse carefully explaining a game with unnecessarily expanding it. The designers of Tuesday Knight Games‚Äô award-winning TTRPG Mothership have successfully resisted that urge. The science fiction horror game‚Äôs final form, a first edition starter set, knows exactly what it...

item.content:encoded: Image: Nintendo Including a lesser Rare game, a Japan-only collectable, and a Satoru Iwata classic No plans for the holiday weekend? An insatiable thirst for retro gaming? Nintendo‚Äôs got your back. In the early hours of July 4, the company added no less than seven Nintendo Entertainment System games to the Nintendo Switch Online service, and it‚Äôs as eclectic a list as you could wish for. item.description: Image: Molleindustria Not feeling fireworks this year? Try learning about socialism instead Happy Fourth of July, I guess. Not feeling so patriotic after the one-two punch of the disastrous Trump-Bi...
item.content:encoded: Image: Molleindustria Not feeling fireworks this year? Try learning about socialism instead Happy Fourth of July, I guess. Not feeling so patriotic after the one-two punch of the disastrous Trump-Biden debate on June 27 and the Supreme Court turning our presidents into unimpeachable monarchs on July 1? Same, buddy. On the (very small, dim, fleeting) bright side, it‚Äôs a great time to talk about socialism. And it‚Äôs always a great time to talk about games, which is why I‚Äôm revisiting Molleindustr...

item.content:encoded: The Salem prize was established in 1968 and named in honor of Rapha√´l Salem (1898-1963), a mathematician famous notably for his deep study of the links between Fourier series and number theory and for pioneering applications of probabilistic methods to these fields.
